ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Defect-dominated optical emission and enhanced ultraviolet photoconductivity properties of ZnO nanorods synthesized by simple and catalyst-free approach

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
We report on the defect-dominated light emission and ultraviolet (UV) photoconductivity characteristics of ZnO nanorods (NRs) fabricated using a facile, cost-effective, and catalyst-free thermal decomposition route under varying reaction temperatures. The morphological and structural studies reveal the formation of homogeneous quality nanorods in large scale at the highest reaction temperature of 600 ∘C. The luminescence feature of the nanorods is dominated by the defect related emission over the typical band edge emission. The variation of band-edge and native defect-related emission response of the samples has been correlated to the morphology and microstructure. In photoconductivity studies, the I–V characteristics of the ZnO NRs prepared at different reaction temperatures in dark and under UV illumination (λ=365 nm) follow the power law, i.e., IαV
r . An enhanced ultraviolet photodetection has been observed in the nanorods fabricated at the highest reaction temperature of 600 ∘C. The sample prepared at highest reaction temperature of 600 ∘C exhibits UV photosensitivity value (photo-to-dark current ratio) of around 1.18×103, which is much higher in magnitude compared to that of the samples prepared at lower reaction temperatures. The enhanced photoconductivity may be assigned to the development of uniformity and homogeneity of the nanorods. Further development of such ZnO nanostructures can form the basis of promising prototype luminescent and UV photodetecting devices.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Currently, there has been a great deal of interest in the construction and integration of one-dimensional (1D) semiconducting materials for the development of various types of functional nanoscale devices such as transistors [1], light-emitting diodes (LED) [2], detectors and optical switches [3, 4], gas and chemical sensors [5], photovoltaics and solar cells [6, 7], nanolasers [8], etc. Research on 1D nanometer-sized materials, especially semiconductor nanorods, have attracted considerable interest because of great potential in optoelectronic nanodevices and functional materials [1–8].

Zinc-oxide (ZnO), being a wide band-gap of ∼3.37 eV and having high exciton binding energy of ∼60 meV at room temperature, is one of the most promising and attractive semiconducting candidates for applications in various photonic and optoelectronic devices [2–5, 7, 9–11]. Nanorods of ZnO have recently received considerable attention from scientific communities and researchers because of the possibility to combine the unique optical and electronic characteristics of the material. The synthesis of 1D ZnO nanostructures has also been of growing interest owing to their promising applications in nanoscale optoelectronic devices. Significant effort has been delivered in the past decade to develop methodologies in the preparation of ZnO nanostructures and studying their optical and optoelectronics properties. In recent years, various works have been reported in the field of synthesis of ZnO nanostructures to optimize an approach that is compatible with the current device fabrication technologies and also simpler, low-cost, catalyst-free, and scalable for high yield.

Till now numerous studies have been made on production and application of 1D ZnO [4, 5, 12–18]. Most recently, metal-organic chemical vapor deposition [12], porous template method [13], chemical vapor deposition [4, 14], aqueous solution method [15, 16], electrochemical deposition [17], solid-state reaction method [5, 18], etc. have been employed, where zinc-acetate dihydrate (ZAD) has been the preferred choice as a chemical agent owing to its low solubility, low decomposition temperature, and minimal contamination. However, in the above synthesis methods, most of these require higher synthesis temperature, strictly controlled synthesis environment, high synthesis cost, complex synthesis reactions, expensive equipment, and complicated operation. Therefore, for wide range of applications of ZnO in functional nanodevices, a facile, simple, low-cost, and high-yield productive synthesis process is desirable, while, however, aqueous solution methods are usually performed at lower temperature and take at least several hours.

Among various synthesis processes, thermal decomposition method is important for the scientific research and technological applications in deciding the thermal stability and other electrical, optical, and photoresponse properties of materials as functions of temperature. It is a very common and simplest approach for synthesizing ZnO nanostructures and has been adopted by many researchers [9, 19–23]. In comparison to other methods, the thermal decomposition in the present study offers a simple, low-cost, catalyst-free, and high-yield productive method for preparation of low-dimensional ZnO nanostructures, which brings an opportunity to correlate the structural, optical, and ultraviolet photoconductivity characteristics of ZnO NRs.

The wide band gap of ZnO is attractive for achieving UV light-emitting devices operational at room temperature. In contrast to that, the presence of Zn- and O-related various native defects in ZnO makes it very promising for the fabrication of visible light-emitting devices. Apart from the defect-related PL emission, these native defects are also found to have influence on the ultraviolet photoconductivity of ZnO. The low dimensionality and large surface-to-volume ratio play a fundamental role in the overall photodetection performance [24]. The photodetection capability of semiconductor thin films [25], nanoparticles [15, 16, 26], nanorods [27], nanoribbons [28], nanobelts [29], and nanowires [3, 4, 30–33] are under study for variety of materials. In the present study, we have adopted a simple, low-cost, catalyst-free, and direct mass-scale productive approach for the preparation of high-purity ZnO nanorods using thermal decomposition of zinc-acetate dihydrate (ZAD) at 200–600 ∘C for reaction time of 12 h. The optical properties including UV-visible optical absorbance, photoluminescence (PL), and ultraviolet photoconductivity characteristics of the ZnO nanorods synthesized at different reaction temperatures have been studied in detail. The obtained ZnO NRs prepared at higher reaction temperature exhibited excellent UV photoconductivity characteristics.

Section2.Heading: Sample preparation
Section2.Para: The zinc acetate dihydrate (ZAD) [Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, Merck, 99.0 %] powder was used as the precursor to prepare ZnO nanorods at different reaction temperatures [9]. 1 g of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O was taken into a crucible and then placed in a muffle furnace at different reaction temperatures of 200 ∘C, 400 ∘C, and 600 ∘C for 12 h without any special atmospheric condition. Finally, ZnO NRs are obtained in powder form.

Section2.Heading: Characterization
Section2.Para: The structural, morphological, and optical properties of the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku D/MAX–2200H/PC, Cu Ka radiation), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), UV-visible absorption spectroscopy (Perkin Elmer LS-35 spectrometer), and photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy (Perkin Elmer LS-55 fluorescence spectrometer).

Section2.Heading: Measurements of photoconductivity characteristics
Section2.Para: In order to study the photoconductivity characteristics, the current vs. voltage (I–V) characteristics, temporal response (i.e., rise and decay curves) and spectral response were studied at room temperature using a cell-type device [34]. The cell was prepared by putting a thick layer of powdered sample in between two Cu electrodes having a spacing of 1 mm and area of illumination is 0.25 cm2. Hg lamp of 300 W is used as photo-excitation sources. A stabilized dc field (50 V/cm to 500 V/cm) was applied across the cell. Current vs. voltage (I–V) characteristics in dark and under ultraviolet illumination of 365 nm was measured using a digital dc nano-ammeter. The rise and decay of photocurrent were recorded in air and vacuum (10−2 mm of Hg to create oxygen-deficient ambient) using RISH Multi-18S with adapter RISH Multi SI-232. The spectral response of photocurrent was measured at a fixed bias voltage of 20 V by illuminating the cell with UV-visible spectral region (365–691 nm) using a set of filters.

Section2.Heading: Structural characterization
Section2.Para:
The structural properties of ZnO NRs samples prepared at various reaction temperatures have been investigated by XRD. Figure 1(a) shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of ZnO NRs prepared at various reaction temperatures of 200 ∘C, 400 ∘C, and 600 ∘C for 12 h. It can be seen that all of the diffraction peaks can be indexed as ZnO with wurtzite hexagonal phase (space group P63 mc, JCPDS card no. 75-0576) [9]. No other characteristic peaks of impurities such as Zn and Zn(OH)2 are observed, indicating that ZnO has been successfully synthesized by the present process. The higher intensity of (101) peak over other peaks suggests the preferred orientation along (101) plane. It can be noticed that for the sample grown at 600 ∘C, the intensity ratio corresponding to (101) and (002) planes is quite higher (2.11) than that of the samples grown at 200 ∘C and 400 ∘C (1.87 and 1.82), as shown in Fig. 1(b). The fact that the intensity of higher (101) peak for the sample grown at highest temperature (600 ∘C), indicates the good crystal quality and purity of the sample. Again, the full-width half-maxima (FWHM) of the (002) peak are found to decrease from 0.0072 rad to 0.0068 rad as the synthesis temperature was increased from 200 ∘C to 600 ∘C and indicate a change in dimension of the nanostructures.
Fig. 1
(a) X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns and (b) a closer view of the prominent peaks of ZnO NRs synthesized by thermal decomposition method at various reaction temperatures

Section2.Heading: Morphology characterization
Section2.Para:
The typical FE-SEM images of the samples reveal the development of elongated ZnO nanostructures at reaction temperatures of 200 ∘C to 600 ∘C and are shown in Fig. 2(a–f). It is clearly evident from Fig. 2(a, b) for sample prepared at reaction temperature of 200 ∘C that the ZnO nanorods are characterized by diameter in the range of 70–170 nm and length varying from 340 nm to 1.5 μm. The micrographs of the sample also reveal the presence of large amount of irregular particles. Again, the diameter and length of nanorods synthesized at 400 ∘C are found to be lying the range 50–70 nm and 125–625 nm, respectively (Fig. 2(c, d)). In this case the nanorods are accompanied by very few irregular particles. Figure 2(e, f) reveals that the ZnO NRs prepared at 600 ∘C have the diameter in the range of 20–35 nm, while their length has been found within 40–100 nm range. When the reaction temperature is increased to 600 ∘C, the uniformity and homogeneity of the ZnO nanorods have been found to be increased with no signature of irregular particles as seen in the previous samples. The rapid decomposition of ZAD at the higher temperature leads to accelerated nucleation and growth of the nanostructures leading to the formation of uniform nanorods. The modification in particle distribution in the three categories of samples can also be supported by the XRD results. As a result of diminishing of smaller particles, the FWHM of the (002) peak was found to decrease on increasing the synthesis temperature.
Fig. 2
Low- and high-magnification FE-SEM images of ZnO Nanorods synthesized by thermal decomposition method at reaction temperature of (a, b) 200 ∘C, (c, d) 400 ∘C, and (e, f) 600 ∘C for 12 h

Section3.Heading: UV-visible absorption spectroscopy
Section3.Para:
Optical absorption spectra of the prepared ZnO NRs samples have been recorded using UV-visible absorption spectroscopy at room temperature after dispersing the samples in double distilled water, with double distilled water being a reference. Figure 3(a) shows the UV-vis optical absorption spectra of ZnO NRs prepared at different decomposition temperatures of 200 ∘C, 400 ∘C, and 600 ∘C for 12 h. The onset of this rapid change in absorption coefficient is called the fundamental absorption edge. Figure 3(a) clearly exhibits excitonic absorption peaks located at 370 nm (∼3.34 eV), 376 nm (∼3.29 eV), and 381 nm (∼3.25 eV) for the reaction temperatures of 200 ∘C, 400 ∘C, and 600 ∘C, respectively. The corresponding energy values of the absorption peaks of the nanorods are blue shifted with respect to the bulk counterpart having absorption peak at 386 nm (∼3.23 eV at room temperature) [15]. In general the blue shift of absorption peak arises due to two different reasons, doping with higher concentration of impurity atoms [35] and quantum confinement effect [36]. Since the present investigation does not deal with any sort of impurity doping, the possibility of impurity led blue shift of absorption peak is discarded. Hence, the observed higher values of the absorption energy signify the quantum confinement effect arising due to the finite diameter of the nanorods, which leads to the restriction of electron motion along two directions. We can also observe that as the reaction temperature is increased, the absorption peak exhibits a progressive redshift, and band gap energy shifts to lower values. The redshift relating to the energy band gap narrowing toward higher reaction temperature could be related to the diminishing of the smaller particles with increase in synthesis temperature. In the sample prepared at 200 ∘C, the presence of smaller nanoparticles is evident from the SEM micrographs, while no signature of the nanoparticles is seen in the SEM image of the nanorods prepared at 600 ∘C. It is speculated that these nanoparticles contribute largely to the absorption feature. Owing to the higher value of surface to volume ratio of the nanoparticles, the absorption peak is found to be blue shifted for the sample containing larger number of nanoparticles.
Fig. 3
Room temperature (a) UV-visible absorption spectra and (b) PL spectra of ZnO NRs by thermal decomposition method at different reaction temperatures

Section3.Heading: Photoluminescence
Section3.Para:
The photoluminescence spectra of ZnO nanorods are recorded by dispersing the powder samples in double distilled water and then exciting by a photon of wavelength 325 nm at room temperature. The room temperature photoluminescence spectra of ZnO nanorods prepared at different decomposition temperatures are shown in Fig. 3(b). ZnO typically exhibits one emission peak in ultraviolet region, just below the onset of absorption and one or more peaks in the broad visible luminescence range. The UV band is assigned to the radiative annihilation of excitons [15, 37]. Commonly in PL, the visible emission consists of green emission and other emission peaks such as violet, blue, blue-green, and yellow emission peaks [15, 18, 37–39]. Though the origin of the visible emissions is still a controversial issue and a number of explanations based on various kinds of zinc and oxygen related defects have been proposed, the defect-related green emission is still under debate and needs thorough discussion. The origin of visible emission band is attributed to the presence of crystal imperfections and various nonstoichiometric intrinsic defects such as oxygen vacancies (Vo), zinc vacancies (VZn), oxygen interstitials (Oi), zinc interstitials (Zni), and oxygen antisites (OZn). The peak positions describing several kinds of zinc- and oxygen-related defects are investigated in previously reported works [15, 37, 38]. For a reaction temperature of 200 ∘C, the PL spectrum exhibits several emission peaks including defect-related broad visible emissions at ∼449 nm (2.76 eV), ∼467 nm (2.65 eV), blue-green emission located at around ∼481 nm (∼2.56 eV), broad peak at ∼492 nm (2.52 eV), green emission ∼545 nm (2.27 eV), and a strong broad UV emission peak ranging from 386–395 nm. The UV emission band is related to near band-edge (NBE) emission of the ZnO and attributed to the recombination of free excitons by exciton–exciton collision process [15, 37]. The small emission feature located at ∼449 nm is attributed to singly ionized Zn interstitials (
$\mathrm{Zn}_{\mathrm{i}}^{+}$ ), while peak located at ∼467 nm is attributed to singly ionized zinc vacancy (
$\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{Zn}}^{-}$ ) [38]. A blue–green emission centered at ∼481 nm is ascribed to the radiative transition of an electron from the shallow donor level of Zni to an acceptor level of neutral VZn [40]. The broad emission peak centered at around ∼492 nm is corresponding to singly ionized oxygen vacancy (
$\mathrm{V}_{0}^{+}$ ) [41]. The broad green emission peak located at ∼545 nm may be assigned to oxygen interstitial (Oi) [42]. The green luminescence has been attributed to the oxygen vacancies, zinc vacancies, oxygen interstitial as well as donor–acceptor pairs [39]. The oxygen vacancies are major defects that are responsible for green PL emission. In pure ZnO, out of three charge states specifically Vo,
$\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{o}}^{-}$ , and
$\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{o}}^{2-}$ the singly ionized oxygen vacancies are anticipated to be responsible for green visible luminescence [43]. Liao et al. [44] has reported luminescence mechanism based on the recombination related to oxygen vacancies. At some instances it is also reported due to the oxygen antisite (OZn) defects [15]. However, in the present case of low decomposition temperature of 200 ∘C, this may be due to the presence of oxygen interstitials or may be due to surface defects, which include remains of acetate and OH groups [39]. In the samples grown at 400 ∘C, the
$\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{Zn}}^{-}$ -related emission gets improved, while the green emission is found to be quenched significantly. Further, for the increase in reaction temperature up to 600 ∘C, the PL intensity gets reduced more significantly. The reduction in UV emission is attributed to the increase in carrier transfer to deep defect levels by their radiative relaxations [18]. The decrease in defect-related visible emission may be attributed to the lowering of radiative defect concentrations [45]. The green emission is also found to be absent in this case. It can be noticed in the PL spectra of the samples prepared at 400 ∘C and 600 ∘C that there is an improvement in the shoulder of the PL spectra (within 420–450 nm regime), which can be assigned to the evolution of Zn interstitial related defects. Note that the emission response due to neutral and ionized Zn interstitial (Zni and
$\mathrm{Zn}_{\mathrm{i}}^{+}$ ) defects in ZnO are generally found at ∼428 and ∼449 nm, respectively [38]. So we can infer that upon increasing the reaction temperature, the Zni-related emissions get improved as more and more Zn atoms participate in the process owing to the faster decomposition of ZAD. The absence of Oi defects in these two cases has been witnessed as they are utilized in the formation of more Zn–O bonds. This fact is also supported by the XRD results, where the improvement in the crystal quality of the samples has been observed.

Section2.Heading: Photoconductivity
Section2.Para: Generally, ZnO is considered as an n-type semiconductor due to presence of oxygen vacancies and other native defects. It is well established that the photoconductivity in ZnO consists of two processes; one is a bulk-related process, which is a fast process associated with the oxygen molecules adsorbed in the grain boundaries of the material. On the other hand, the second one is a surface-related process, which is a slow process and attributed to the processes of adsorption and photo-desorption of oxygen molecules on the surface of nanorods. In the study of photoconductivity, the variation of photocurrent as a function of various parameters including applied voltage, energy of illumination, temperature, and other parameters gives us very efficient information regarding the nanomaterials.

Section3.Heading: Voltage dependence of dark-current and photocurrent
Section3.Para:
Figures 4(a) and 4(b) show the I–V characteristics of the ZnO NRs prepared at different reaction temperatures in dark and under UV light illumination (λ=365 nm), respectively, on semi-logarithmic scale. The variation of dark current (I dc) with bias voltage in typical log–log scale (shown in the inset of Fig. 4(a)) clearly depicts linear trend with different slopes in lower and higher voltage regimes. The variation of current with the applied voltage may be expressed by power law, i.e., IαV
r , where r is the slope of a straight line. For all the reaction temperatures, the variation of dark current (I dc) with applied voltage is found to be superlinear (r>1) in nature at low- and high-voltage regimes. The superlinear variation of dark current (1<r<2) suggests that some carriers are being injected from the electrodes [15, 16, 18, 23, 46, 47]. As the reaction temperature increases from 200 ∘C to 600 ∘C, the dark current varies with voltage according to power index more than two (r>2) at lower- and higher-voltage regimes. This indicates that the current flow in these systems is limited by space charge and is called space-charge-limited current (SCLC). Because of high surface-to-volume ratio of nanorods, the process of adsorption and desorption of chemisorbed oxygen molecules on the surface of nanorods play an important role in the space-charge-limited current. The chemisorptions of oxygen molecules contribute to SCLC by depleting free electrons, thereby causing the concentration of injected free carriers to increase the free career concentration [48]. The physisorbed O2 molecules on surface of ZnO NRs capture the injected electrons and get chemisorbed. With increase in reaction temperatures up to 600 ∘C, the crystals quality improves, and all the surface traps due to physisorbed oxygen molecules get filled, and then the current becomes SCLC. If the material has traps, then space-charge-limited current will also be determined by traps. This trap-limited space-charge-limited current (TLSCLC) varies with voltage, according to a power index greater than two [47].
Fig. 4
I–V characteristics in (a) dark, (b) under UV light illumination (λ=365 nm). Inset shows the corresponding log–log plots and (c) spectral response (at 20 V) of the ZnO nanorods prepared by thermal decomposition method at various reaction temperatures

The dependence of photocurrent (I pc) with applied voltage on log–log scale is shown in the inset of Fig. 4(b) and can be expressed by power law for high- and low-voltage regions. The system of all ZnO nanorods shows super linear variation at low- and high-voltage regimes. For higher reaction temperature of 600 ∘C, both the dark current and the photocurrent enhanced; this may be due to removal of the adsorbed oxygen molecules from the surface thereby releasing trapped carriers for conduction. It is important to distinguish between the effects of oxygen adsorption on the carrier injection and those on the carrier transport. In the ZnO system, where the current is space-charge limited, it is easy to see that decrement in the trapping of free charges will lead to an increase in effective mobility and the current [26]. The values of r for dark current and photocurrent are listed in Table 1.

Section3.Heading: Spectral response
Section3.Para: Figure 4(c) shows the spectral response of photocurrent at 20 V of ZnO nanorods prepared at different reaction temperatures. The photocurrent shows a sharp onset from 400 nm, and low photoresponse is observed in the longer wavelength range indicating higher selectivity for the ultraviolet photosensors. It can be inferred that the response spectrum of ZnO NRs is directly related to the energy band gap structure. The enhancement in photosensitivity is due to the electron-hole pairs excited by the incident of light with sufficient photon energy higher than the band gap. The small increase of photocurrent in higher wavelength region is due to transition of carriers from localized defect sates lying in the band gap to the conduction band [13, 26, 28], which is also evidenced in PL emission spectra as shown in Fig. 3(b). The values of visible rejection ratio (Q), i.e., the ratio of maximum photocurrent in UV region to the minimum photocurrent in visible region, are given in Table 1. The results indicate that the value of Q is much higher for ZnO NRs sample prepared at highest reaction temperature compared with that formed at lower reaction temperatures suggesting the evolution of large quantity of uniform nanorods.

Section3.Heading: Rise and decay of photocurrent
Section3.Para:
Figure 5(a) shows the rise and decay of the photocurrent with time of ZnO NRs prepared at different reaction temperatures in response to switching “on” and “off” condition under ultraviolet illumination of 365 nm. Figure 5(b) shows rise and decay of photocurrent response in vacuum, and Fig. 5(c) exhibits photocurrent rise decay under the periodic (2 min) UV illumination (in vacuum and in air ambient) for the ZnO NRs sample fabricated at highest reaction temperature of 600 ∘C. For the reaction temperature of 200 ∘C, when UV light is switched on, the photocurrent rises from 5.33×10−1 nA to 1.33×102 nA, which is more than 80 % of its peak value within 251.65 s and reaches a peak value of 1.56×102 nA and gets saturated. When light is switched off the photocurrent falls to 80 % of its value of photocurrent in 200 s. As the reaction temperature increases from 200 ∘C to 400 ∘C, the photocurrent reaches a maximum value of 208.29 nA and then starts decaying slowly during steady illumination. The photocurrent rises to more than 80 % of its peak value within 240 s and falls to 80 % of its value of photocurrent just before cessation of illumination within 318 s. Further increase of reaction temperature up to 600 ∘C, the photosensitivity (photo-to-dark current ratio, i.e., ∼1.18×103′) is found to be highly enhanced. The maximum photocurrent for the sample is found to be 20–25 times more than that of sample prepared at lower reaction temperatures. In this case, when the UV light is switched on, the photocurrent rises sharply and achieves its peak value of 3855 nA within 70 s. This fast response is due to quick generation of electron and hole pairs as a result of absorption of photon energy. After attaining a peak value (3855 nA), the photocurrent decreases exponentially and then becomes nearly constant even during steady illumination. Similar anomalous nature of photocurrent in which the photocurrent decreases during steady UV illumination has been previously reported in the literature [30–34]. The decrease in photocurrent during the steady illumination has been suggested to the readsorption of
$\mathrm{O}_{2}^{-}$ molecules or recombination of electrons to the Zni recombination center. In the present case, the second factor is responsible for the decrease in photocurrent during the steady illumination. In the PL spectra, the developments of Zni defect with increase in reaction temperatures are well evident. At reaction temperature of 200 ∘C, moderate amounts of Zni defects are present, and, as a result, there is no change in photoconductivity observed during steady illumination. For the reaction temperature of 400 ∘C, there is increment in the Zni defects as revealed from PL spectra, and results in the demonstration of decrement in photocurrent during steady illumination, while for the highest reaction temperature of 600 ∘C, there is a substantial increment in Zni defects, and the sample shows sharp decrease in steady-state photoconductivity. The whole mechanism is summarized in the schematic diagram of Fig. 6(a–c). The decay time constants during steady illumination for all the samples are listed in the Table 1. In ZnO NR grown at reaction temperature of 200 ∘C, the values of β, the total photocurrent-to-darkcurrent ratio, i.e., photosensitivity is about 3.89, while the value increases by an order of magnitude to ∼43 when the reaction temperature increases to 400 ∘C. The photosensitivity is enhanced further to ∼1182 when the reaction temperature increases up to 600 ∘C. Such highly enhanced UV photosensitivity in ZnO NRs formed at higher reaction temperature of 600 ∘C by simple, catalyst-free approach, i.e., thermal decomposition of zinc acetate dihydrate in air has not yet been reported. The β values of all the samples are listed in Table 1. The results indicates that the ZnO NRs fabricated at highest reaction temperature are much more UV sensitive than the samples prepared at lower reaction temperatures (200 ∘C, 400 ∘C). It is well known that at equilibrium in the dark, oxygen molecules of the atmosphere are adsorbed onto the ZnO nanorod surfaces by capturing the free electrons from the n-type ZnO due to oxygen vacancy as follows: O2 (g) + e− →
$\mathrm{O}_{2}^{-}$ (ad). These adsorbed oxygen ions create a low-conductivity depletion layer near the surface of ZnO NRs [4, 14, 26, 32]. These adsorbed atoms decrease the conductivity by a reduction of both the density of free electrons and effective conducting thickness of the nanorods. Due to large surface-to-volume ratio of nanostructures, these effects are more prominent and play an important role in photosensitivity of materials. On illumination of UV light of photon energies above the band gap, electron-hole pairs (EHPs) are generated. The photo-generated holes migrate to surface along the potential gradient produced by band bending either via discharge of the negatively charged adsorbed O2 ions through h+ + O−2 (ad) → O2 (g) to photodesorb oxygen from the surfaces or effectively get trapped at the surfaces, resulting in an increase in the free carrier concentration and a decrease in the width of depletion layer [4, 14, 26, 32]. This leads to an enhancement of carrier injection and transport, producing a persistent photocurrent. When the illumination is turned off, oxygen readsorbs on the surfaces of nanorods, and the photocurrent decreases.
Fig. 5
Photocurrent rise and decay (a) in air for samples grown at 200, 400, 600 ∘C, (b) in vacuum for sample grown at 600 ∘C, and (c) under the periodic (2 min) UV light illumination for sample grown at 600 ∘C at 20 V both in vacuum and air
Fig. 6
Schematic representation of ZnO NRs exhibiting the decrease in photocurrent mechanism even during steady UV illumination for the samples fabricated at various reaction temperatures of (a) 200 ∘C, (b) 400 ∘C, and (c) 600 ∘C

Enhanced UV photosensitivity may be attributed to the evolution of large quality of uniform nanorods at reaction temperature of 600 ∘C. In this case, the development of large number of nanorods can be seen in the SEM micrograph. The participation of large number of nanorods in this case results in the adsorption of more oxygen molecules on the surface of ZnO nanorods. Hence, upon UV illumination, a large number of electrons will be liberated and would effectively increase the photoconductivity. The slow rise and decay may be attributed to the dominance of surface-related processes of adsorption and desorption of oxygen molecules [4, 32]. To further explore the influence of adsorption on the photoconduction properties of the sample of reaction temperature of 600 ∘C, the photoconductivity is also measured in vacuum as shown in Fig. 5(b). In this case the rise and decay of photocurrent are much slower than those of measured in air. The photocurrent reached to a steady state value (14.72 μA) in ∼10 min, which is higher than the photocurrent in air is by the order of 3. These comparatively slow and prolonged rise and decay of photocurrent are originated from the oxygen-deficient atmosphere. The oxygen-deficient ambient makes the photocurrent growth itself slower in vacuum as evidenced in Fig. 5(b), so there is no carrier relaxation during steady UV illumination [32]. The dark current in the vacuum is also higher than in air and may be attributed to the increased concentration of free electrons as a result of oxygen deficient atmosphere. This gives the nonavailability of oxygen molecules in vacuum, which is supposed to be adsorbed on the surface of ZnO NRs by capturing the free electrons. This is similar to the work reported earlier [14, 31–34] in the literature for ZnO systems. The anomalous nature of photocurrent has been observed in the air atmosphere even during steady UV illumination. This anomalous behavior of photocurrent may also be attributed to the variation of the surface depletion region [44]. The decay portion of sample at a reaction temperature of 600 ∘C during steady illumination is well fitted with biexponential equation [32], I=A 1exp(−t/τ 1)+A 2exp(−t/τ 2)+I 0, where the two relaxation time constants τ 1 and τ 2 are estimated to be 101.18 s and 1178.70 s, respectively, exhibiting the faster component followed by slower components for at least two types of defects and trap states lying within the band gap of materials. When the UV light is switched off, the photocurrent decreases exponentially and also well fits with biexponential equation, I=B 1exp(−t/τ
d1)+B 2exp(−t/τ
d2)+I 0, where the two time constants τ
d1 and τ
d2 are calculated to be 41.69 s and 295.21 s, respectively, demonstrating the much faster decay component followed by slower components. It also indicates the presence of defect states and traps inside the band gap. The rise and decay time constants τ
r , τ
d1, and τ
d2 obtained for ZnO NRs prepared at different reaction temperatures are shown in Table 2. Now the rise and relaxation time are found to highly depend on the surface and microstructure of the nanorod samples. The photocurrent in the samples of reaction temperature 200–400 ∘C shows slow rise and decay time constants and suggests that the photoconduction is mainly governed by surface-related process. For the reaction temperature of 600 ∘C, the fast rise and decay time constants may be attributed to the dominance of the bulk-related processes over surface-related process. This arises due to the improvement in surface condition of the nanorods fabricated at the highest reaction temperature. The presence of lower number of surface defects is the vital factor for the improvement of the surface quality. This fact has been well evidenced in PL spectra of the nanorods [Fig. 3(b)]. The sample prepared at reaction temperature of 600 ∘C also shows good switching behavior as shown in Fig. 5(c).

Section3.Heading: Trap depth determination
Section3.Para: The decay portions of photocurrent after the cessation of excitation for all the samples have been taken for the calculation of p-value, i.e., the probability of an electron escaping from a trap and trap depth (E). The photocurrent decay curves for all samples are obtained by the linear fitting of the photocurrent curve on a logarithmic scale. The fitting demonstrated that the decay portion of each samples is governed by the biexponential law. This implies that the traps of deferent natures are situated at different energy depths in the band gap.

The p-values corresponding to different exponentials have been calculated by the relation [15, 16, 18, 23, 46, 47] I=I 0exp(−pt), where I 0 is the current at the moment when light is interrupted, and I is the photocurrent at any instant of time. Earlier, Randal and Wilkins [49] have demonstrated the theory for the emptying of traps considering the probability of an electron escaping from a trap. This probability is defined by the relation p=Sexp(−E/kT), where the exponential term is a Boltzman factor involving the trap depth E, the absolute temperature T, and the Boltzman constant k (1.381×10−23 J/K). The S is the frequency factor, i.e., the “attempt to escape frequency.” The S can be interpreted as the number per second that the quanta from crystal vibrations (phonons) attempt to eject the electrons from the traps, multiplied by the probability of transition from trap to the conduction band (S=109 at room temperature). This equation also requires the assumption that S and E are independent of temperature, that the electrons freed from traps are not re-trapped, and that freed electrons undergo radiative, rather than dissipative transitions.

The trap depths (E) corresponding to different exponentials can be estimated with combining above equations and are expressed by
$$E = kT \biggl[ \log_{e}S - \log_{e}\frac{\log_{e}\frac{I_{0}}{I}}{t} \biggr]. $$

The probabilities of an electron escaping from the traps and trap depths (trap ionization energies, eV) corresponding to the biexponential decay portions for all the samples prepared at various reaction temperatures are calculated and listed in Table 2.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: A catalyst-free approach has been used to prepare ZnO NRs by thermal decomposition process at various reaction temperatures from 200 ∘C to 600 ∘C. X-ray diffraction and electron microscopy studies reveal the production of nanorods with better crystal quality and morphology in the samples fabricated at 600 ∘C. On the other hand, photoluminescence spectra of all the samples show the band-edge-related UV emission and native defect-related visible emissions. The sample prepared at higher reaction temperature results in a significant reduction in defect-related emission intensity owing to the improvement of crystal quality over the other samples. Photoconductivity analysis shows enhanced photosensitivity with highly increased visible rejection ratio. The photoconductivity process in the nanorods prepared at 200 and 400 ∘C is found to be dominated by the surface-related process, while the bulk-related process predominates the photoconductivity of the sample prepared at 600oC. The maximum photocurrent for the sample prepared at higher reaction temperature of 600 ∘C is 20–25 times more than that of the sample prepared at lower reaction temperatures. Further exploration in this context may be useful to fabricate future luminescent and photoconductive devices based on ZnO nanorods.
